"Description": "(Dot.) In the default mode
column3: this matches any character except a newline"

"Description": "(Caret.) Matches the start of the string
column3: and in ``MULTILINE`` mode also matches immediately after each newline"

"Description": "Matches the end of the string or just before the newline at the end of the string
column3: and in MULTILINE mode also matches before a newline"

"Description": "Causes the resulting RE to match 0 or more repetitions of the preceding RE
column3: as many repetitions as are possible"

"Description": "Causes the resulting RE to match 1 or more repetitions of the preceding RE"
"Causes the resulting RE to match 0 or 1 repetitions of the preceding RE"
" Adding ``?`` after the qualifier makes it perform the match in non-greedy or minimal fashion; as few characters as possible will be matched"
"Specifies that exactly m copies of the previous RE should be matched; fewer matches cause the entire RE not to match."
"Causes the resulting RE to match from m to n repetitions of the preceding RE
column3: attempting to match as many repetitions as possible."

"Description": "Causes the resulting RE to match from m to n repetitions of the preceding RE
column3: attempting to match as few repetitions as possible."

"Description": "Either escapes special characters (permitting you to match characters like '*'
"any character from ``a`` to ``z``"
"any character from ``A`` to ``Z``"
"any digit from ``0`` to ``9``"
"will match ``a``

column3: where A and B can be arbitrary REs
column4: creates a regular expression that will match either A or B."

"Description": "Matches whatever regular expression is inside the parentheses
column3: and indicates the start and end of a group"

"Description": "substring matched by the group is accessible via the symbolic group name name"
"A backreference to a named group; it matches whatever text was matched by the earlier group named name. ``(?P<tag><.*?>)text(?P=tag)`` or ``(?P<tag><.*?>)text\1``"
"Matches the contents of the group of the same number. Groups are numbered starting from 1. For example
column4: but not ``thethe`` (note the space after the group)."

"Description": "Unicode decimal digit ``[0-9]``
"Unicode whitespace characters ``[\t\n\r\f\v]`` and non-breaking spaces"
"Unicode word characters; this includes most characters that can be part of a word in any language
column3: as well as numbers and the underscore"
